author: Jon Montesa
title: The gentleman’s guide
text:
by Jon Montesa
October 3, 2015 Bamboo Manalac
Former Rivermaya vocalist Bamboo Mañalac said a gentleman is respectful to everyone “in reference not only to women but to your common man, to every human being.”
Frank Magalona, son of the late iconic rapper Francis Magalona, pointed out that it’s also about having self-respect.
“So whatever God had given you, accept that,” he said.
Hunk Fabio believes respect should go hand-in-hand with being caring. “(A gentleman) is not gonna worry all the time about himself, but he’s gonna be worried or concerned (about others), making sure everyone is good. For me, being a gentleman is more of the person being caring,” he said.
Model-actor Victor Basa believes a gentleman should “know how to walk on the right side of the sidewalk” and, funny enough, should “know how to tie a tie.”
Tested?
They say a true gentleman would not engage in bad behavior. Have they been in a situation where they chose to err, we asked.
“Of course, many times. ’Cause we’re just human beings. Things happen,” Frank said.
“I’m sure there have been a few times,” Bamboo added.
Fabio admitted he’s not perfect either but he always tries to keep himself in check. “Sometimes all it needs is for one to recall proper values,” he said.
Victor shared he sometimes gets stuck doing nothing where it is expected or appropriate. He recalled a bus ride to Ilocos where he saw this woman looking for a seat. “I was like, ‘How many hours is this trip? Should I offer my seat?’ I was thinking and thinking until finally I told myself, ‘Okay I’m gonna offer my seat.’ But somebody already offered her one.”
Gentlemen’s creed
Given the chance to create a guideline for a gentleman, Bamboo said it should, first and foremost, include the tenet “listen and learn.”
For Fabio, the most important thing to put in there should be “observe proper decorum” and the concept of “delicadeza.”
Frank added the doctrine should also include the line “respect yourself and respect your neighbor.”
Victor would go for subtlety. “Because you don’t want to be ostentatious, you don’t wanna be obnoxious. If you’re a true gentleman you don’t find the need to prove anything,” he explained.
‘Amoy gwapo’
Being the latest ambassadors of a body spray brand, we asked Bamboo, Frank, Victor and Fabio what they think of “amoy gwapo.”
For Bamboo, a scent is the “extra layer” one puts on to add to one’s confidence.
Frank Magalona, Fabio Ide and Victor Basa
“Sometimes the smallest thing is what catches people’s attention. So a scent is like a ‘calling card.’ I want to smell good because first impression lasts,” the 37-year-old singer songwriter said.
Frank believes it is important because one’s body is a “temple” and it deserves proper attention. Victor thinks smelling good is necessary especially in his line of work.
“I just really like smelling good, even when I was a kid. It’s nice to hear that people appreciate you because of being mabango…” Fabio said.
Pick and choose
When connecting with a girl, which of these do they consider most helpful: good looks, talent, or sense of humor?
It’s none of the above for Bamboo. He said, “Making a connection is not about you, it’s about the other person. Everything should come automatically after. Like, after you establish a connection, you already look good to him or her. You’re already funny. So, to me it’s about knowing the other person, their spirit, their character, then getting in rhythm with that.”
Fabio chose sense of humor. “I’m a happy person and I love people that bring positivity, too.”
Victor thinks so, too, “(Because) if you take everything too seriously, that would be sad,” he said.
Frank picked talent believing “it’s much more substantial than looks and sense of humor.”
